G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A, and applicable jurisdictional provisions, this Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court Department.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Newton District Court because the incident giving rise to this action occurred at Whiting Park in Newton, Massachusetts, which lies within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable rules, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).raw_text: Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006) (duty of reasonable care arises where a reasonably prudent person would anticipate harm)
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The court expressly states a general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, and it immediately conditions that duty on foreseeability of the risk of harm. That language directly matches the claimed proposition about Massachusetts common law imposing a duty of reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others, and it is part of the court’s doctrinal discussion, not a stray dictum.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses duty in the context of landowner liability and the limits of a landowner’s duty regarding adjacent public highways, but it does not announce any general Massachusetts common-law rule that "every person" has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm. Instead, it frames duty more narrowly, tied to land ownership, control, and specific undertakings, and ultimately finds no duty on these facts. The case therefore cannot be relied on as authority for a universal duty of reasonable care owed by all persons.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. See O’Gorman v. Antonio Rubinaccio & Sons, 408 Mass. 758, 760 (1990); Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629 (1989). Whether such a duty exists is a question of law. Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 12 (1991), citing Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., supra. In determining whether the defendant had a duty to be careful, we look to existing social values and customs, as well as to appropriate social policy.

Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.raw_text: Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 158, 161–63 (1933) (liability where plaintiff fell while fleeing threatened harm)
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.proposition: In particular, one who owns, keeps, or controls a dog owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent the dog from causing foreseeable injury to others, including injury caused by a reasonably foreseeable attempt to escape the dog’s threatening conduct.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The case concerns a store’s premises-liability duty and expressly holds there was no liability because, at common law, even an owner or keeper of a dog is not liable absent knowledge (or reason to know) of the dog’s dangerous propensities. It does not discuss injuries from fleeing a threatening dog or recognize a broader duty to prevent all foreseeable injuries from a dog’s threatening conduct; instead, it emphasizes that dogs are ordinarily harmless and that, without notice of dangerousness, no duty is breached. Thus it does not support the proposition that an owner/keeper must exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable injuries, including those from escape attempts, in the absence of such notice.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Apart from statute even an owner or keeper of a dog, as our cases recognize, is not liable for bodily injuries inflicted by it in the absence of proof that he knew, or at least should have known, its dangerous propensities… and in the absence of proof of some fault of such owner or keeper. … Where, as in the present case, no statute intervenes, the liability for bodily injuries caused by dogs falls within the general principles governing liability for injuries caused by animals ordinarily harmless.”

Hill v. Winsor, 118 Mass. 251, 259\u2013.raw_text: Hill v. Winsor, 118 Mass. 251, 259–60 (1875) (foreseeable peril created by defendant’s conduct)
Hill v. Winsor, 118 Mass. 251, 259\u2013.proposition: In particular, one who owns, keeps, or controls a dog owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent the dog from causing foreseeable injury to others, including injury caused by a reasonably foreseeable attempt to escape the dog’s threatening conduct.
Hill v. Winsor, 118 Mass. 251, 259\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with general negligence principles and foreseeable injury arising from defendants’ operation of a tug-boat, not with duties of owners or keepers of dogs. While it discusses liability for injuries suffered in a reasonably foreseeable attempt to escape peril created by a defendant’s negligent conduct, it does so in the context of maritime/structural collision, not animal control. Thus, it may be analogically relevant on foreseeability, but it does not establish or address the specific dog-related duty stated in the proposition.
Hill v. Winsor, 118 Mass. 251, 259\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “They must have also found that the plaintiff was himself in the exercise of due care in attempting to escape the peril to which he was exposed by the defendants’ conduct, and that his injury was therefore due solely to the defendants’ negligence. … It cannot be said, as matter of law, that the jury might not properly find it obviously probable that injury in some form would be caused to those who were at work on the fender by the act of the defendants in running against it. This constitutes negligence…”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 640–41 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: A defendant’s duty of reasonable care extends to injuries that are a foreseeable consequence of the risk created, including injuries suffered while a plaintiff reasonably attempts to avoid danger caused by the defendant’s negligence.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The provided text is a concurrence focused on rejecting the majority’s broader causation analysis and simply agreeing that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk created by the defendant’s negligence. It does not articulate or endorse the principle that a defendant’s duty of reasonable care extends to injuries suffered while a plaintiff reasonably attempts to avoid danger caused by the defendant’s negligence. Instead, it emphasizes lack of foreseeability in this case, without adopting the broader duty proposition stated.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence." Ante at 640-641.

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: A defendant’s duty of reasonable care extends to injuries that are a foreseeable consequence of the risk created, including injuries suffered while a plaintiff reasonably attempts to avoid danger caused by the defendant’s negligence.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The case clearly discusses foreseeability and proximate cause, holding that the defendant can be liable where injury is a reasonably foreseeable result of leaving a dangerous instrumentality unsecured in an area frequented by foreseeable plaintiffs. However, the opinion does not address, even implicitly, the specific scenario of injuries suffered while a plaintiff reasonably attempts to avoid danger created by the defendant’s negligence; the plaintiff here was a passive bystander struck by the forklift. Thus it supports the general foreseeability/duty concept but not the more specific “rescue/avoidance” aspect of the proposition as stated.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … It was also reasonably foreseeable…that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area, such as those visiting the ships.”

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 173.proposition: Under G.L. c. 140, § 173 and related municipal and state provisions, municipalities may require that dogs be under restraint or on leash in public areas; Newton has posted and enforced such rules in its parks, requiring that all dogs be kept on leashes.

Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 190, 192\u.raw_text: Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 190, 192–93 (1958) (recognizing liability associated with dog‑related injuries under Massachusetts law)
Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 190, 192\u.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to control his dog so as to prevent the dog from menacing, charging at, or otherwise endangering park users, including Plaintiff.
Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 190, 192\u.case_name: McPadden v. W. J. Halloran Co.
Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 190, 192\u.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt provided concerns workers’ compensation and the ‘common employment’ doctrine between a steel fabricator and a crane contractor; it does not discuss dogs, dog-related injuries, or any duty to control animals in a park or elsewhere. The citation line referring to Glidden v. Szybiak and dog-related liability appears only in the user’s parenthetical, not in the reproduced opinion text. On this record, the case does not provide authority for a duty to control a dog to prevent menacing or charging park users.
Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 190, 192\u.relevant_excerpt: This action of tort was brought in the right of the plaintiff, an employee of Stafford Iron Works, Inc. (Stafford), for the benefit of the plaintiff and of Stafford’s insurer under the workmen’s compensation act (G. L. c. 152) against a contractor of Stafford which, it could have been found, negligently injured the plaintiff. The case involves application of the doctrine of “common employment,” restated in Clark v. M. W. Leahy Co. Inc. 300 Mass. 565, 567-570, which implements the purpose of the workmen’s compensation act…

Brown v. Bolduc, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 909,.raw_text: Brown v. Bolduc, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 909, 910 (1990) (discussing duties of dog owners)
Brown v. Bolduc, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 909,.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to control his dog so as to prevent the dog from menacing, charging at, or otherwise endangering park users, including Plaintiff.
Brown v. Bolduc, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 909,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses negligence duties related to dogs only to reject liability for the parents/landowners and emphasizes that it was for the owner-keeper (the daughter) to handle the dog. It does not articulate or apply a general duty of a dog owner to exercise reasonable care to prevent the dog from menacing or charging park users; instead, it rests liability on the strict dog-bite statute and states that negligence is irrelevant under that statute. Thus the case does not support the specific reasonable-care duty proposition asserted.
Brown v. Bolduc, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 909,.relevant_excerpt: "No jury could find in reason that this charged the mother, as landowner, still less the father, with breach of a duty of due care in the meaning of Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 706-707 (1973). As the judge indicated in a sound discussion at the time he directed the verdict, it would be preposterous on these facts to charge the parents with some obligation to intrude themselves and give warning to Sonia’s guests about danger from a dog or to insist on other precautions. It was for the owner-keeper to handle her dog."

Graci v. Damon, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 160, 16.raw_text: Graci v. Damon, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 160, 163–64 (1977) (discussing proximate cause and foreseeable escape efforts)
Graci v. Damon, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 160, 16.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that “a negligent actor is liable not only for harm caused directly but also for harm resulting from a reasonable attempt by the other to escape the danger created by the actor’s negligence.”
Graci v. Damon, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 160, 16.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns municipal group insurance contributions, statutory interpretation, and collective bargaining under Massachusetts law. It does not address negligence, proximate cause, or injuries resulting from escape efforts. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition about liability for harm resulting from reasonable attempts to escape danger created by a negligent actor.
Graci v. Damon, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 160, 16.relevant_excerpt: The provided text contains no discussion of negligence, proximate cause, or injuries arising from escape attempts; it is entirely about interpretation of G. L. c. 32B, § 7 and § 7A, and related collective bargaining issues.

Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a tortfeasor is liable for all damages that are the natural and probable consequences of the negligent act.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion is concerned with defining and applying Massachusetts’ proximate cause standard, not with stating a broad rule that a tortfeasor is liable for all damages that are the natural and probable consequences of the negligent act. The court emphasizes continuous, operative causation and discusses natural and probable consequences only as a test for remoteness and causal connection, not as an independent measure of the scope of damages. Thus, it does not clearly endorse the claimed proposition as a general damages rule.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The exception to the charge in the light of the medical testimony raises the question whether the injury which by reason of the negligence of the defendant came to the intestate could under the law have been found to be the proximate cause of her death. … In McDonald v. Snelling… it was said: ‘… The test is to be found, not in the number of intervening events or agents, but in their character, and in the natural and probable connection between the wrong done and the injurious consequence.’”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence on the part of Plaintiff is alleged, Plaintiff states that any such negligence was less than that of Defendant and, in any event, her recovery is governed by G.L. c. 231, § 85, which permits recovery so long as her negligence, if any, was not greater than the negligence of Defendant.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest on her damages as allowed by G.L. c. 231, § 6B (interest in tort actions for personal injuries) and G.L. c. 235, § 8.

G.L. c. 235, \u00a7 8.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest on her damages as allowed by G.L. c. 231, § 6B (interest in tort actions for personal injuries) and G.L. c. 235, § 8.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Plaintiff is also entitled to costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules of civil procedure.
